Flatland_Cavalry:
{{Short description|American country and Americana band}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Flatland Cavalry | image = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | origin = [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], [[Texas]] | genre = [[Country music|Country]], [[Americana (music)|americana]], [[folk rock]], [[Texas country music|Texas country]] | years_active = 2012–present | label = Flatland Cavalry, [[Interscope Records|Interscope]] | website = https://www.flatlandcavalry.com/ | current_members = Cleto Cordero
Reid Dillon
Wesley Hall
Jonathan Saenz
Jason Albers
Adam Gallegos | past_members = Laura Jane }} '''Flatland Cavalry''' is a [[country music|country]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] band from [[Lubbock, Texas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/flatland-cavalry-mn0003425378/biography|title=Flatland Cavalry|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=January 5, 2017}} The band's original members were vocalist Cleto Cordero, drummer Jason Albers, bassist Jonathan Saenz, guitarist Reid Dillon, and violinist Laura Jane. Jane departed the band in July 2018 and was replaced by Wesley Hall.{{cite web | url=http://kokefm.com/flatland-cavalry-announce-homeland-insecurity/ | title=Flatland Cavalry Announce 'Homeland Insecurity' | publisher=KOKE FM | accessdate=19 November 2018}} Flatland Cavalry was formed in 2012 by Cordero and Albers, who were college roommates in [[Midland, Texas|Midland]] and performed together before moving to Lubbock, where the rest of the members came together by 2014.{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/go/music/2015-05-07/flatland-cavalry-performing-cd-release-party-thursday-blue-light|title=Flatland Cavalry performing CD release party Thursday at the Blue Light |publisher=Lubbock Online|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kcbd.com/story/31672180/lubbock-band-flatland-cavalry-rises-to-no-2-on-itunes-country-chart|title=Lubbock band Flatland Cavalry rises to No. 2 on iTunes Country Chart|publisher=KCBD|date=April 7, 2016|accessdate=January 5, 2017}} In May 2015, the band's debut [[extended play|EP]], titled ''Come May'', was released after a [[crowd-funding]] campaign was used to finance its production. On April 1, 2016, their first full-length album, ''Humble Folks'', was released to positive reviews and comparisons to the music of the [[Turnpike Troubadours]].{{cite web|url=http://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/8906-2/|title=Flatland Cavalry: "Humble Folks"|publisher=Lone Star Music Magazine|date=April 4, 2016|accessdate=January 5, 2017}} ''Humble Folks'' peaked at number 17 on the Billboard Americana/Folk albums chart{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7327275/flatland-cavalry/chart?f=1071|title=Flatland Cavalry - Chart History (American/Folk albums)|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=January 5, 2017}} and number 38 on the Top Country Albums chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7327275/flatland-cavalry/chart?f=320|title=Flatland Cavalry - Chart History (Top Country Albums)|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=January 5, 2017}} The band's second studio album, ''Homeland Insecurity'', was released on January 18, 2019. [[Kaitlin Butts]], who is married to Cordero and an accomplished musician in her own right, is a frequent collaborator with the band and a oft-seen part of their live shows. {{Cite web|title=Shots with the Band Featuring Kaitlin Butts & Cleto Cordero of Flatland Cavalry {{!}}|url=http://texasmusicpickers.com/shots-with-the-band-featuring-kaitlin-butts-cleto-cordero-of-flatland-cavalry/|access-date=2021-01-20|language=en-US}} == Formation == The roots for the formation of Flatland Cavalry were first laid when Cleto Cordero and Jason Albers began playing at local venues while rooming together at [[Midland College]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.midlandlivingmagazine.com/2019/05/28/200570/flatland-cavalry-takes-texas-by-storm|title=Flatland Cavalry takes Texas by Storm {{!}} Midland Living|last=|first=|date=|website=Midland Living|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-10-30}} The two had been jamming together since junior high but it was not until they moved to Lubbock in 2012 that the band began to take shape. It was here, while studying at [[Texas Tech University]], that the duo met Laura Jane at a house party. Jonathan Saenz and Reid Dillon joined the rest in 2014 and the band's lineup was complete. Cordero himself began playing the guitar at age 14 and wrote his first song by the time he was 17 years old for Lee High School's Rebel Lee Court Awards Ceremony. He writes most of the band's songs apart from playing the role of lead guitarist and singer with Jason Albers on drums, Jonathan Saenz on bass, Reid Dillon on guitar and Wesley Hall on fiddle. Hall took the place of Laura Jane when she parted ways with the band in 2018. == Discography == === EPs === ==== ''Come May'' (2015) ==== The band released its first EP in 2015, gathering funds for its production via a crowdfunding platform. The band reached its goal of $5,000 in just eight days, a testament to the fan following they had already mustered through live performances. '''Track list'''{{Cite web|url=https://www.flatlandcavalry.com/listen|title=LISTEN|website=Flatland Cavalry|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-30}} # "No Shade of Green" # "Love Me in the Water" # "Summertime Love" # "Missing You" # "Ain't Over You Yet" ==== ''Songs To Keep You Warm'' (EP) (2022) ==== '''Track list''' # "Mountain Song" # "Damaged Goods" # "How Long" (feat. Kaitlin Butts) # "Parallel" (feat. Ashley Monroe) # "If We Said Goodbye" # "Show Me Now Which Way To Go" === Albums === ==== ''Humble Folks'' (2016) ==== It was the release of its debut EP followed by its first album, ''Humble Folks'', in 2016 that really got the ball rolling, with music insiders comparing Flatland to the likes of the [[Turnpike Troubadours]], lauding the band for its youthful blend of country, folk, Americana and rock. ''Humble Folks'' peaked at #38 on the Billboard Country Music Top 100 chart and #17 on the American/Folk Albums chart. '''Track list''' # "One I Want" # "A Good Memory" # "February Snow" # "Tall City Blues" # "Coyote (The Ballad of Roy Johnson)" # "Devil Off My Back" # "Stompin' Grounds" # "Goodbye Kiss" # "A Life Where We Work Out" (feat. Kaitlin Butts) # "Traveler's Song" # "Humble Folks" ==== ''Homeland Insecurity'' (2019) ==== In 2018, Laura Jane left the band and was soon replaced by Wesley Hall on fiddle. With the new lineup in place, the quintet released their second album, ''Homeland Insecurity'', in 2019; three years after the release of their debut.{{Cite web|url=https://eventseeker.com/artist/63269-flatland-cavalry|title=Flatland Cavalry - Artist Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=eventseeker.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-10-30}} In the time that lapsed between the two, the band toured extensively, honing their skill as musicians and drawing on their experiences to craft their sophomore work.{{Cite web|url=https://sixshootercountry.com/2019/01/22/flatland-cavalry-homeland-insecurity-review/|title=Flatland Cavalry - Homeland Insecurity {{!}} Review|date=2019-01-22|website=Six Shooter Country|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-10-30}} As the band's primary songwriter, Cordero penned lyrics for ''Homeland Insecurity'' are markedly more sophisticated than his previous songs. The album was widely well-received and praised for its distinctive sound.{{Cite web|url=http://www.texasmusicpickers.com/homeland-insecurity-by-flatland-cavalry-was-well-worth-the-wait/|title="Homeland Insecurity" by Flatland Cavalry was Well Worth the Wait|website=Texas Music Pickers|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-30}} '''Track list''' # "Come Back Down" # "Honeywine" # "Old School" # "Other Side of Lonesome" # "Back to Me" # "Living by Moonlight" # "Ashes" # "Lonely Then" # "Pretty Women" # "Sleeping Alone" # "Years from Now" ==== ''Welcome to Countryland'' (2021) ==== '''Track list''' # "Country Is..." # "Some Things Never Change" # "A Cowboy Knows How" # "Gettin' By" # "Well-Spent Time" # "Life Without You" (feat. Kaitlin Butts) # "No Ace In the Hole" # "It's Good To Be Back ('Round Here Again)" # "Tilt Your Chair Back" # "Fallen Star" # "Daydreamer" # "Dancin' Around a Fire" # "Off Broadway" # "...Meantime" (feat. Hailey Whitters) ====''Wandering Stars'' (2023)==== The Texan country-Americana band announced the release of their fourth studio album, “Wandering Star” on Oct, 27th 2023.{{Cite web |date=2023-11-01 |title=Flatland Cavalry Announces Fourth Studio LP: "Wandering Star" {{!}} TicketTaper Presale Codes, Concert Ticket, Tour Dates, Concert News |url=https://tickettaper.com/flatland-cavalry-announces-fourth-studio-lp-wandering-star/ |access-date=2023-11-01 |website=tickettaper.com |language=en-US}} The album, is their first release on Interscope Records, which follows their successful 2022 EP, “Songs To Keep You Warm”. “Wandering Star” consists of 13 solo tracks and one collaborative track featuring Kaitlin Butts. '''Track list''' # "The Provider" # "The Best Days" # "Only Thing At All" # "Last American Summer" # "Mornings With You" (feat. Kaitlin Butts) # "Let It Roll" # "Spinnin’" # "Don’t Have To Do This Like That" # "New American Dream" # "Oughta See You (The Way I Do)" # "A Thousand Miles An Hour" # "Burned Out Flame" # "Forgotten" ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Country music groups from Texas]] [[Category:Musical groups from Lubbock, Texas]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Texas]]
